titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Thomas Wilfred Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by William E. Brown, Jr. and staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 10:41

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, drawings, photographs, printed material, clippings, and miscellanea documenting the professional career of Thomas Wilfred, inventor of the clavilux and a prominent artist and developer of lumia, an artform which utilizes light as the medium of expression. Additional materials detail Wilfred's musical career as a lute player. The development of lumia within the field of kinetic art and the prominent role of Thomas Wilfred in this development, as an inventor, artist, performer, and teacher are documented. Correspondence with individuals, fellow artists, universities and organizations, and museums detail Wilfred's attempts to develop, promote and market the clavilux. Correspondents include: Eugene Epstein, Alfred N. Goldsmith, the Museum of Modern Art, W. Christian Sidenius, the Whitney Museum of Art, and several universities. Material detailing clavilux construction attempts and experimental work Wilfred performed, including extensive numbers of drawings, photographs and sketches of clavilux models, patents on the clavilux, contracts for performances, research data for design plans, compositions for "visual symphonies," and clippings and printed material on performances and recitals are included. Other materials include research data, clippings, and writings on the artform of lumia, and additional information for compositions written by Wilfred and articles published by Wilfred and others.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Thomas Wilfred, 1983; W. Christian Sidenius, 1994-1995; Raymond Epstein, 1996; and Georgia M. Newton, 2009 (Accession 2010-M-026).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Permission to publish from the digital audiorecording of Patricia Marx's inteview with Wilfred (ACCN 2015-M-046) must be obtained from New York Public Radio. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Thomas Wilfred Papers (MS 1375). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, drawings, photographs, printed material, clippings and miscellanea documenting the professional career of Thomas Wilfred, inventor of the clavilux and a prominent artist and developer of lumia, an artform which utilizes light as the medium of expression, 1914-1968. Additional materials detail Wilfred's musical career as a lute player, 1914-1918.

The development of lumia within the field of kinetic art and the prominent role of Thomas Wilfred in this development, as an inventor, artist, performer, and teacher are documented. Correspondence with individuals, fellow artists, universities and organizations, and museums details Wilfred's attempts to develop, promote, and market the calivilux. Correspondents include: Eugene Epstein, Alfred N. Goldsmith, the Musuem of Modern Art, W. Christian Sidenius, the Whitney Musuem of Art, and several universities.

Material detailing the construction and experimental work Wilfred performed, including extensive numbers of drawings, photographs, and sketches of clavilux models, patents on the clavilux, contracts for performances, research data for design plans, compositions for "visual symphonies," and clippings and printed material on performances and recitals are arranged in the papers. Other materials include research data, clippings, and writings on the artform of lumia, and additional information for compositions written by Wilfred and articles published by Wilfred and others.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Thomas Wilfred was born on June 18, 1889, in Naestved, Denmark. He studied music in Europe, achieving international status as a performer on the lute. He moved to the United States in 1916, and began to develop and perform on the clavilux and promote lumia as an art form. Wilfred died on August 15, 1968 in Nyack, New York. Wilfred toured the United States performing clavilux recitals, and appeared with such artists as Leopold Stokowski. He constantly designed new clavilux models, built and headed the Art Institute of Light in New York, adapted the clavilux for scenic projections in theatre productions, and composed over fifty compositions for the clavilux.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in two series and four additions: I. Correspondence, 1923-1968. II. Clavilux, Lumia, and Miscellanea, 1914-1968.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: For an index of books that are included in this collection, please consult theBibliographical Index.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Wilfred's professional correspondence as inventor of the clavilux, the light projection machine used to create works of "lumia," a kinetic artform which utilizes light as a medium. Wilfred built clavilux machines of various sizes and capabilities, ranging from large models for amphitheatre performances to smaller versions for use in homes. This correspondence includes items about theatres, universities, and locales where clavilux performances and exhibits were staged, including Clairol, Inc. of New York, the Musuem of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Musuem of Art, and the Whitney Museum of American Art, and the state universities of Georgia, Nebraska, Oregon, and Washington. Correspondence with Alfred N. Goldsmith concerns the mutual efforts of the two men to market the clavilux as a commercial venture. Similarly, letters exchanged with Eugene Epstein detail the interests of a typical art collector in the availability of the clavilux and lumia compositions for personal use. W. Christian Sidenius wrote Wilfred frequently from 1960-1968 and the two men discussed their work on lumia in detail.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically by individual and/or organization.

did.unittitle: Carroll, Richard and Wright, G. Scott

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the research data, drawings, designs, patents, contracts, photographs, writings, clippings, and miscellanea relating to Wilfred's construction of clavilux models and performance of lumia compositions. The series is arranged in three sections: CLAVILUX, LUMIA, and MISCELLANEA.

CLAVILUX files contain extensive clippings files on specific performances, models, and the Art Institute of Light (folders 86-101). Numerous drawings and sketches of clavilux models and components are also organized in this section, and include several large design plans found in boxes 22 and 23. Specific clavilux installations and performances at Carnegie Hall in New York City, and the Hotel Sherman in Chicago are also documented. Photographs (box 10 and folio 27) illustrate several clavilux models and picture Thomas Wilfred installing machines and performing various works.

LUMIA files contain detailed instructions and plans for performing many of the compositions or "Opus" works which Wilfred authored. Major compoments of the clavilux, central to the performance of a lumia composition, are also documented, including the direct beam projector (folder 197), and the multiplate scenic projector (folder 210). The projected scenery application of lumia, that is, the use of the artform as the scenery in the production of a play, details another aspect of Wilfred's work (folders 214-216; 240).
MISCELLANEA files contain material on Wilfred's musical career as a lute player in Europe, obituary notices, and photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in three sections: CLAVILUX, LUMIA, and MISCELLANEA. Material in each section is arranged alphabetically by topic and/or type.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Large poster is in poor condition.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Many of the negatives and prints are in their original enclosures. Researchers should request cotton gloves from the Reading Room Service desk prior to handling visual materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Lumia compositions, color-related research, John Healy work, and projected theater scenery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes lantern slides for Star I and II, and glass slides and negatives for theater projection scenery and various compositions and projects.

did.unittitle: Glass negatives of various compositions and projects

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes 20 W. 22nd Street and Grand Central Palace projection room (480 Lexington Avenue), New York City; Model G and early home-recorded compositions; 2100 watt, 60 volt direct-beam projector for scenery; Seamus unit; Opus 162 Lucata; and various compositions and projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession comprises correspondence between Wilfred and Raymond Epstein regarding the purchase of a composition.
